Explanation: Those columns describe the structure of the table itself, i.e., metadata.

Question: Which of the following searching algorithm is fastest?
Explanation: Binary search is the fastest among the given options when the list is sorted.

Question: Where is linear searching used?
Choice B: When the list has only a few elements
Choice C: When performing a single search in an unordered list
Choice D: When the list has only a few elements and When performing a single search in an unordered list

Question: How can Jump Search be improved?
Choice A: Step size should be other than sqrt(n)
Choice C: Begin from the kth item, where k is the step size

Explanation: Exponential search finds a range, then applies binary search.

Question: Which of the following searching algorithm is fastest when the input array is not sorted but has uniformly distributed values?
Explanation: If the array is not sorted, linear search is the only viable simple approach.

Question: What is the time complexity of Z algorithm for pattern searching (m = length of text,  n = length of pattern)?"
Explanation: Z algorithm runs in O(m + n).

Question: In which of the cases uniform binary search fails compared to binary search?
Choice B: Many searches will be performed on several arrays of the same length
Choice C: Many searches will be performed on the same array
Choice D: A table lookup is generally faster than an addition and a shift
Explanation: Uniform binary search generally fails due to more complex code.

Question: Interpolation search is a variation of?
Explanation: Interpolation search is a variation of binary search.

Question: Which of the following step is taken after finding an element having value greater than the element being searched?
Choice A: binary search takes place in the forward direction
Choice B: binary search takes place in a backward direction
Choice C: linear search takes place in the forward direction
Choice D: linear search takes place in the backward direction

Question: Which of the following is not an advantage of Fibonacci Search?
Choice A: When the element being searched for has a non uniform access storage
Choice B: It can be applied efficiently on unsorted arrays
Choice C: Can be used for large arrays which do not fit in the CPU cache or in the RAM
Choice D: Can be used in magnetic tapes
Explanation: Fibonacci search is not efficient on unsorted arrays.

Question: In which of the following case jump search will be preferred over exponential search?

Choice B: when the given array is very large in size
Choice C: jumping backwards takes significantly more time than jumping forward
Choice D: jumping forward takes significantly more time than jumping backwards
Explanation: Jump search is simpler when the array size is very small.

Question: What is the best case for linear search?
Explanation: The best case for linear search is finding the target at the first check, O(1).

Question: What is the worst case for linear search?
Explanation: The worst case for linear search requires checking all elements, O(n).

Question: What is the best case and worst case complexity of ordered linear search?
Explanation: Ordered linear search is O(1) in the best case and O(n) in the worst.

Question: Which of the following is a disadvantage of linear search?
Choice B: Greater time complexities compared to other searching algorithms
Explanation: Linear search is slower compared with more efficient algorithms.

Question: What is the advantage of recursive approach than an iterative approach?
Choice B: Less code and easy to implement
Choice D: More code has to be written
Explanation: A recursive approach often needs less code and is easier to implement.

Question: Given an input arr = {2,5,7,99,899}; key = 899; What is the level of recursion?

Explanation: The mid elements checked are 90 at first, then 99.

Question: What is the average case time complexity of binary search using recursion?
Explanation: The average case of binary search by recursion is O(logn).

Question: Which of the following is not an application of binary search?
Choice A: To find the lower/upper bound in an ordered sequence

Question: Binary Search can be categorized into which of the following?
Explanation: Binary search divides the problem in half each time (divide and conquer).

Question: What is the time complexity of binary search with iteration?
Explanation: The time complexity of iterative binary search is O(logn).

Question: Which of the following sorting algorithms is the fastest for sorting small arrays?
Explanation: Insertion sort is generally fastest for very small arrays.

Question: What is the advantage of selection sort over other sorting techniques?
Choice A: It is faster than any other sorting technique
Choice C: It works best for inputs which are already sorted
Choice D: It requires no additional storage space
Explanation: Selection sort needs no extra storage beyond the input array.

Question: Which of the following method is used for sorting in merge sort?
Explanation: Merge sort uses merging to combine sorted halves.

Question: Which of the following sorting algorithm does not use recursion?
Explanation: Heap sort does not use recursion in its main sorting phase.

Question: Merge sort uses which of the following method to implement sorting?
Explanation: Merge sort uses merging to implement sorting.

Question: Which of the following sorting algorithms is the fastest?
Explanation: Quick sort is usually the fastest in practice on average.

Question: Quick sort uses which of the following method to implement sorting?
Explanation: Quick sort uses partitioning around a pivot.

Question: In heap sort, after deleting the last minimum element, the array will contain elements in?
Explanation: A min-heap sort results in ascending (increasing) order in the array.

Question: Which of the following sorting algorithm is stable?
Explanation: Tim sort (used by Python) is stable.

Question: Which of the following sorting algorithm uses the method of insertion?
Explanation: Among the listed, cycle sort is typically classified under insertion-like positioning.

Question: Which of the following pair of sorting algorithms are stable?
Explanation: Gnome sort and merge sort are both stable techniques.

Question: What is the worst case complexity of bubble sort?
Explanation: The worst case complexity of bubble sort is O(n^2).

Question: What is the average case complexity of bubble sort?
Explanation: The average case complexity of bubble sort is also O(n^2).

Question: Which of the following is not an advantage of optimised bubble sort over other sorting techniques in case of sorted elements?
Choice C: Detects whether the input is already sorted
Explanation: Bubble sort's optimization does not specifically reduce memory usage over others.

Question: The given array is arr = {1, 2, 4, 3}. Bubble sort is used to sort the array elements. How many iterations will be done to sort the array?
Explanation: Two passes are performed before it detects no swaps are needed.

Question: What is the average case time complexity of merge sort?
Explanation: The average time complexity of merge sort is O(n log n).

Question: What is the auxiliary space complexity of merge sort?
Explanation: Merge sort requires O(n) auxiliary space.

Question: What is the worst case time complexity of merge sort?
Explanation: Worst case time complexity of merge sort is O(n log n).

Question: What will be the best case time complexity of merge sort?
Explanation: Best case time complexity of merge sort remains O(n log n).

Question: What is the worst case time complexity of a quick sort algorithm?
Explanation: Quicksort's worst case time is O(n^2).

Question: Which of the following methods is the most effective for picking the pivot element?
Explanation: Median-of-three partitioning is often the most effective pivot selection.

Question: Which is the safest method to choose a pivot element?
Choice A: choosing a random element as pivot
Choice B: choosing the first element as pivot
Choice C: choosing the last element as pivot
Explanation: The safest pivot choice is the median-of-three method.

Question: What is the average running time of a quick sort algorithm?
Explanation: On average, quick sort runs in O(n log n).

Question: Which is the worst method of choosing a pivot element?
Explanation: Picking the first element (especially in an ordered array) is the worst pivot method.

Question: Which among the following is the best cut-off range to perform insertion sort within a quick sort?
Explanation: A typical cutoff is in the range of 5-20 for insertion sort within quick sort.

Question: The given array is arr = {2,3,4,1,6}. What are the pivots that are returned as a result of subsequent partitioning?
Explanation: Standard quicksort partitioning returns pivots 1 then 3 on successive splits.

Question: What is the average case complexity of QuickSort?
Explanation: The average case complexity of quick sort is O(n log n).

Question: Depth First Search is equivalent to which of the traversal in the Binary Trees?
Explanation: DFS is like pre-order in binary trees.

Question: Time Complexity of DFS is? (V ??number of vertices, E ??number of edges)
Explanation: DFS complexity is O(V + E).

Question: The Data structure used in standard implementation of Breadth First Search is?
Explanation: A queue is used in the standard BFS implementation.

Question: The Depth First Search traversal of a graph will result into?
Explanation: DFS traversal produces a spanning tree of the graph.

Question: Which of the following is not an application of Depth First Search?
Choice A: For generating topological sort of a graph
Choice B: For generating Strongly Connected Components of a directed graph
Explanation: BFS is typically used in peer-to-peer networks, not DFS.

Question: When the Depth First Search of a graph is unique?
Choice A: When the graph is a Binary Tree
Choice B: When the graph is a Linked List
Choice C: When the graph is a n-ary Tree
Choice D: When the graph is a ternary Tree

Question: Regarding implementation of Depth First Search using stacks, what is the maximum distance between two nodes present in the stack? (considering each edge length 1)
Explanation: In a stack-based DFS, adjacent nodes on the stack differ by at most 1 edge.

Question: In Depth First Search, how many times a node is visited?
Choice C: Equivalent to number of indegree of the node
Explanation: In DFS, each node is visited exactly once.

Question: Breadth First Search is equivalent to which of the traversal in the Binary Trees?
Explanation: BFS corresponds to a level-order traversal in a binary tree.

Question: Time Complexity of Breadth First Search is? (V ??number of vertices, E ??number of edges)
Explanation: BFS complexity is O(V + E).

Question: Regarding implementation of Breadth First Search using queues, what is the maximum distance between two nodes present in the queue? (considering each edge length 1)
Explanation: In a typical BFS queue, any two nodes differ by at most one level (distance 1).

Question: In BFS, how many times a node is visited?
Choice C: Equivalent to number of indegree of the node
Explanation: Each node is enqueued and visited exactly once in BFS.

Question: The first step in the naïve greedy algorithm is?
Choice D: calculating the maximum flow using trial and error
Explanation: The naive greedy method first picks augmenting paths with higher flow.

Question: Dijkstra's Algorithm is the prime example for ___________
Explanation: Dijkstra's algorithm is a classic example of a greedy approach.

Question: Which of the following is/are property/properties of a dynamic programming problem?
Choice D: Both optimal substructure and overlapping subproblems
Explanation: Dynamic programming problems have optimal substructure and overlapping subproblems.

Question: Which of the following problems should be solved using dynamic programming?
Explanation: The Longest Common Subsequence is a classic DP problem.

Question: Which of the following problems can't be solved using recursion?
Explanation: A recursive solution fails if there's no base case.

Question: When does the ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException occur?

Question: What are the advantages of arrays?
Choice A: Objects of mixed data types can be stored
Choice B: Elements in an array cannot be sorted

Explanation: Arrays help store multiple items of the same data type conveniently.

Choice B: There are chances of wastage of memory space if elements inserted in an array are lesser than the allocated size
Choice C: Index value of an array can be negative

Question: Assuming int is of 4bytes, what is the size of int arr[15];?

Question: In general, the index of the first element in an array is __________

Question: Which data structure is used for implementing recursion?
Explanation: Recursion is implemented using stack frames.

Question: Linked list data structure offers considerable saving in _____________
Explanation: Linked lists grow as needed, saving space.

Question: Which of the following points is/are not true about Linked List data structure when it is compared with an array?
Choice A: Arrays have better cache locality that can make them better in terms of performance
Choice B: It is easy to insert and delete elements in Linked List
Choice C: Random access is not allowed in a typical implementation of Linked Lists
Choice D: Access of elements in linked list takes less time than compared to arrays
Explanation: Linked lists do not allow fast random access.

Question: Which of the following sorting algorithms can be used to sort a random linked list with minimum time complexity?
Explanation: Merge sort is best for linked lists by minimizing time complexity.

Question: Which of the following is not a disadvantage to the usage of array?
Choice B: There are chances of wastage of memory space if elements inserted in an array are lesser than the allocated size
Explanation: Direct indexed access is an advantage, not a disadvantage.

Question: What is the time complexity of inserting at the end in dynamic arrays?
Explanation: Inserting at the end can be amortized O(1) or O(n).

Question: What is the time complexity to count the number of elements in the linked list?

Question: What is the space complexity for deleting a linked list?

Question: Which of these is not an application of a linked list?

Question: Which of the following is not the utility of DBMS?

Question: For designing a normal RDBMS which of the following normal form is considered adequate?
Explanation: Third normal form is usually sufficient for most RDBMS designs.

Question: __________ command is used in SQL to issue multiple CREATE TABLE, CREATE VIEW and GRANT statements in a single transaction.
Explanation: CREATE SCHEMA lets you bundle multiple create/grant statements.

Question: Every constraint on the table is a logical consequence of the table?

Question: Anomalies are avoided by splitting the offending relation into multiple relations, is also known as
Explanation: Splitting a relation to avoid anomalies is called decomposition.

Question: Which of the following is not a restriction for a table to be a relation?
Choice A: The cells of the table must contain a single value
Choice B: All of the entries in any column must be of the same kind
Choice D: No two rows in a table may be identical
Explanation: The columns do not have to be in a fixed order.

Question: Which of the following gives a logical structure of the database graphically?

Question: The entity relationship set is represented in E-R diagram as
Explanation: Relationship sets are shown as diamonds in E-R diagrams.

Explanation: A weak entity set is identified by its owner set.

Question: Weak entity set is represented as
Explanation: A weak entity set is shown as a double rectangle.

Question: What term is used to refer to a specific record in your music database; for instance; information stored about a specific album?

Question: Does RDBMS have ACID properties?

Question: What is a relation in RDBMS?

Question: Dynamic hashing allows us to?

Choice B: Accommodate the shrinkage of the database

Question: Which of the following constraints RDBS doesn't check before creating the tables?

Question: Which of the following is a good database management practice?

Question: What is/are the disadvantages of implementing tree using normal arrays?

Question: Advantages of linked list representation of binary trees over arrays?

Choice D: Both dynamic size and ease in insertion/deletion

Question: Disadvantages of linked list representation of binary trees over arrays?
Choice B: Extra memory for a pointer is needed
Choice D: Random access is not possible and extra memory with every element
Explanation: Random access is impossible and extra pointer memory is needed.

Question: If binary trees are represented in arrays, what formula can be used to locate a left child, if the parent node has an index i?
Explanation: The left child of index i is found at 2i+1.

Question: Using what formula can a parent node be located in an array?
Explanation: A node's parent index is (i-1)/2.

Question: Which of the following properties are obeyed by all three tree - traversals?
Choice A: Left subtrees are visited before right subtrees
Choice B: Right subtrees are visited before left subtrees
Choice C: Root node is visited before left subtree
Choice D: Root node is visited before right subtree
Explanation: All standard traversals visit the left subtree before the right subtree.

Question: A binary search tree contains values 7, 8, 13, 26, 35, 40, 70, 75. Which one of the following is a valid post-order sequence of the tree provided the pre-order sequence as 35, 13, 7, 8, 26, 70, 40 and 75?

Question: In a binary search tree, which of the following traversals would print the numbers in the ascending order?
Explanation: In-order traversal of a BST produces ascending order.

Question: What is a full binary tree?
Choice A: Each node has exactly zero or two children
Choice B: Each node has exactly two children
Choice C: All the leaves are at the same level
Choice D: Each node has exactly one or two children
Explanation: A full binary tree has each node with either 0 or 2 children.

Question: What is a complete binary tree?
Choice A: Each node has exactly zero or two children
Choice B: A binary tree, which is completely filled, with the possible exception of the bottom level, which is filled from right to left
Choice C: A binary tree, which is completely filled, with the possible exception of the bottom level, which is filled from left to right
Choice D: A tree in which all nodes have degree 2
Explanation: A complete binary tree is filled except possibly the bottom level from left to right.

Question: Which of the following is false about a binary search tree?
Choice A: The left child is always lesser than its parent
Choice B: The right child is always greater than its parent
Choice C: The left and right sub-trees should also be binary search trees
Choice D: In order sequence gives decreasing order of elements
Explanation: In-order of a BST gives ascending order, so "decreasing order" is false.

Question: What is the main characteristic of a B Tree?
Choice A: Each node has a variable number of children within a specified range
Choice B: Nodes are arranged in a binary structure
Choice C: Tree height is logarithmic in the number of elements
Choice D: All nodes store the same number of keys
Explanation: A B Tree node can have a variable number of children within limits.

Question: In a B Tree, what property does the order m define?
Choice A: Maximum number of children a node can have
Choice C: Maximum number of keys a node can have
Choice D: Maximum number of nodes in the tree
Explanation: The order m specifies the maximum children per node.

Question: Which of the following operations can be performed efficiently using a B Tree?
Choice B: Insertion, deletion, and search of keys in a database
Choice C: Finding the shortest path in a graph
Explanation: B Trees efficiently perform insertion, deletion, and search of keys.

Question: What is a significant advantage of using B Trees in database systems?
Choice A: They require less memory than binary search trees
Choice B: They ensure minimal disk I/O operations
Choice D: They can store any type of data without conversion
Explanation: B Trees reduce disk I/O operations significantly.

Question: How do B+ Trees differ from B Trees?
Choice A: B+ Trees are binary trees, while B Trees are multi-way trees
Choice B: In B+ Trees, all keys are stored in leaf nodes and internal nodes act as routing guides
Choice C: B+ Trees do not allow duplicates, while B Trees do
Choice D: B+ Trees have a fixed height, while B Trees have variable height
Explanation: In B+ Trees, all keys reside in leaf nodes; internal nodes guide searches.

Question: What is the advantage of B+ Trees over B Trees in terms of range queries?
Choice A: B+ Trees require fewer comparisons for range queries
Choice B: B+ Trees provide faster access to individual keys
Choice C: Leaf nodes of B+ Trees are linked, providing efficient full-range scans
Choice D: B+ Trees have a simpler structure, making range queries more straightforward
Explanation: Linked leaves in B+ Trees enable efficient range queries.

Question: In a B+ Tree, where are the actual records pointed to by the keys stored?
Explanation: In a B+ Tree, actual records are stored in leaf nodes only.

Question: Why are B+ Trees preferred in database indexing over B Trees?
Choice A: B+ Trees provide faster insertion and deletion operations
Choice B: The linked leaf nodes in B+ Trees make sequential access faster
Choice C: B+ Trees require less disk space
Choice D: B+ Trees are easier to implement
Explanation: B+ Trees allow faster sequential access due to linked leaf nodes.

Question: What is the key property of an AVL Tree?
Choice A: Every node has at most two children
Choice B: The tree is a complete binary tree
Choice C: The difference in height between the left and right subtrees of any node is at most 1
Choice D: All leaf nodes are at the same level
Explanation: An AVL Tree keeps subtree height difference at most 1.

Question: What is the time complexity of insertion in an AVL Tree?
Explanation: AVL Tree insertion runs in O(log n).

Question: Which of the following operations can cause an AVL Tree to become unbalanced?
Choice D: Computing the height of the tree
Explanation: Adding a new node can unbalance an AVL Tree.

Question: What mechanism is used to maintain the balance of an AVL Tree after insertion or deletion?
Explanation: AVL Trees rebalance using rotations after insertions or deletions.

Question: In the context of AVL Trees, what is a rotation?
Choice A: Swapping the values of two nodes
Choice B: Moving a subtree to a different location
Choice C: Changing the structure of the tree without altering the in-order sequence of elements
Choice D: Changing the root of the tree
Explanation: A rotation restructures the tree without changing in-order traversal.

Question: What is the maximum number of rotations needed to balance an AVL Tree after a single insertion?
Explanation: At most two rotations are needed to rebalance an AVL Tree after insertion.

Question: How does the height of an AVL Tree compare to the height of a perfectly balanced binary tree?
Choice B: It can be up to twice as large
Choice C: It can be larger, but no more than log n
Choice D: It can be smaller, but no less than log n
Explanation: AVL height is still O(log n), though slightly taller than perfectly balanced.

Question: Which of the following is true about the deletion operation in an AVL Tree?
Choice A: It cannot cause the tree to become unbalanced
Choice B: It may require rebalancing through rotations
Choice C: It is always performed without rotations
Choice D: It is less complex than deletion in a binary search tree
Explanation: Deletion might cause imbalance and require AVL rotations.

Question: What is a distinctive feature of a Red-Black Tree?
Choice A: Each node is colored either red or black
Choice B: Each node can have up to three children
Choice C: The tree is always perfectly balanced
Choice D: All leaf nodes are at the same depth
Explanation: Each Red-Black Tree node is either red or black.

Question: Which of these properties must a Red-Black Tree satisfy?
Choice A: Every red node must have two black child nodes
Choice B: Every path from a node to its descendant NIL nodes has the same number of black nodes
Explanation: Red-Black Trees require black-height consistency and red nodes cannot have red children.

Question: What is the time complexity of insertion and deletion operations in a Red-Black Tree?
Explanation: Red-Black Tree insertion and deletion remain O(log n).

Question: What action is performed to maintain the Red-Black properties after an insertion or deletion?
Choice D: Converting the tree to a binary search tree and then back to a red-black tree
Explanation: Recoloring and rotations fix Red-Black violations after updates.

Question: In a Red-Black Tree, what does the property "the tree has the same number of black nodes on any path from a node to a descendant leaf" ensure?
Choice B: The tree is height-balanced, with the longest path no more than twice the length of the shortest path
Choice C: All paths have the same length
Choice D: The tree is a full binary tree
Explanation: Consistent black height ensures balanced paths.

Question: Which of the following operations may cause a violation of Red-Black Tree properties?
Choice D: Computing the height of the tree
Explanation: Inserting a node may break Red-Black properties.

Question: What is the maximum height of a Red-Black Tree with n nodes?
Explanation: The maximum height of a Red-Black Tree is about 2*log2(n+1).

Question: Why are Red-Black Trees important in computer science?
Choice A: They provide a worst-case guarantee for insertion, deletion, and search operations
Choice B: They are easier to implement than binary search trees
Choice C: They require less memory than AVL trees
Choice D: They do not require rebalancing after every insertion or deletion
Explanation: Red-Black Trees guarantee O(log n) worst-case operations.

Question: What is a Splay Tree?
Choice A: A tree where recently accessed elements are quick to access again
Choice B: A perfectly balanced binary search tree
Choice C: A binary tree with unique height properties
Choice D: A tree where each node has exactly two children
Explanation: A Splay Tree quickly re-accesses recently accessed elements.

Question: What is the key operation used in Splay Trees to maintain tree properties?
Explanation: Splay Trees use a splaying operation for self-adjustment.

Question: What does the splaying operation in a Splay Tree do?
Choice A: Moves a node to the root through a series of rotations
Choice C: Ensures all leaf nodes are at the same depth
Choice D: Balances the tree perfectly after every operation
Explanation: Splaying moves a node to the root via rotations.

Question: What is the time complexity of search, insert, and delete operations in a Splay Tree in the amortized case?
Explanation: Splay Tree operations run in O(log n) amortized time.

Question: Which of the following scenarios best demonstrates the advantage of a Splay Tree?
Choice A: When the tree is accessed randomly and there are no frequently accessed nodes
Choice B: When certain nodes are accessed frequently and need to be accessed quickly
Choice C: When the tree is used for one-time write and read operations
Choice D: When the tree requires frequent rebalancing to maintain strict height balance
Explanation: Splay Trees excel when some nodes are accessed repeatedly.

Question: What property does a Splay Tree use to ensure that recently accessed elements are quick to access again?
Choice A: The tree rebalances itself after every operation
Choice B: Nodes are colored red or black to indicate their access frequency
Choice C: Frequently accessed nodes are moved closer to the root
Choice D: Leaf nodes are linked together for faster sequential access
Explanation: Splay Trees move frequently accessed nodes closer to the root.

Question: In a Splay Tree, what happens after an element is accessed (searched, inserted, or deleted)?
Choice B: The accessed element is moved to the root of the tree
Choice D: The accessed element is moved to a leaf position
Explanation: After access, the node is splayed to the root.

Question: Why might Splay Trees not be suitable in an environment with parallel or concurrent operations?
Choice A: Because the structure of the tree changes frequently, making it hard to predict
Choice B: Because they are more memory-intensive than other trees
Choice C: Because splay operations are not thread-safe
Choice D: Because they do not support concurrent modifications well due to the restructuring after operations
Explanation: Frequent structural changes complicate parallel use of splay trees.

Question: Which of the following is true about Depth-First Search (DFS) of a graph?
Choice A: It traverses by exploring the highest-depth nodes first before backtracking
Choice B: It can be implemented using a queue data structure
Choice C: It is used to compute the shortest path in a graph
Choice D: It can get trapped in loops or cycles if the graph is cyclic and not properly handled

Question: What is the time complexity of Breadth-First Search (BFS) on a graph?

Question: In Breadth-First Search (BFS), which data structure is typically used to hold the nodes that are next to be visited?
Explanation: A queue is used to implement BFS.

Question: Which of the following scenarios is more efficiently solved using Depth-First Search (DFS)?
Choice A: Finding the shortest path in a weighted graph
Choice B: Finding connected components in a graph
Explanation: DFS efficiently finds connected components in a graph.

Question: What is a key characteristic of Breadth-First Search (BFS)?
Choice B: It visits nodes as far from the root as possible before backtracking
Choice C: It can be used to detect cycles in a directed graph
Choice D: It explores all neighbors of a node before moving on to the next level of nodes
Explanation: BFS explores all immediate neighbors before moving to the next level.

Question: In which case would you prefer BFS over DFS?

Choice B: When the graph has cycles and you want to avoid getting trapped
Choice C: When the solution is likely to be far from the root node
Choice D: When memory usage is a critical concern

Question: Which of the following statements about graph traversal is FALSE?
Choice A: BFS can be used to find the shortest path in an unweighted graph
Choice B: DFS can be implemented both recursively and iteratively
Choice C: BFS always requires more memory than DFS
Choice D: In DFS, if a graph is tree-structured, the traversal visits every edge exactly twice

Question: Which data structure is used to implement a graph using an adjacency list?

Question: In an adjacency matrix representation of a graph, how is an edge between vertices u and v represented?
Choice A: By setting the value at position (u, v) to 0

Question: What is the time complexity of adding a new edge in the adjacency list representation?

Question: Which of the following statements is true for a dense graph (a graph where the number of edges is close to the maximum number of edges)?

Choice B: Adjacency matrix representation is more space-efficient than adjacency list

Question: What is the space complexity of a graph with V vertices and E edges when using an adjacency matrix representation?

Question: Which representation is generally preferred for graphs with lots of vertices but few edges (sparse graphs)?
Explanation: Sparse graphs typically use adjacency lists.

Question: How is a self-loop (an edge that connects a vertex to itself) represented in an adjacency matrix?
Choice A: By setting the value at position (u, u) to 0
Choice B: By setting the value at position (u, u) to 1 or the weight of the edge
Choice C: By leaving the position (u, u) undefined
Choice D: By setting the value at position (u, u) to -1

Question: What is the average time complexity of Quick Sort?
Explanation: Quick Sort averages to O(n log n).

Question: What is the worst-case time complexity of Quick Sort?
Explanation: Quick Sort can degrade to O(n^2) in the worst case.

Question: In Quick Sort, what is the purpose of the partition operation?
Choice A: To divide the array into two halves
Choice C: To rearrange the elements so that all elements less than the pivot are on the left, and all greater are on the right
Choice D: To find the maximum element of the array
Explanation: Partitioning arranges elements so smaller ones go left, larger go right.

Question: Which of the following is not a strategy for choosing a pivot in Quick Sort?

Choice B: Pick a random element as the pivot
Choice C: Pick the median as the pivot
Choice D: Pick the element with the highest value as the pivot

Question: What is the main advantage of Quick Sort over other sorting algorithms like Merge Sort?

Choice D: Quick Sort has a better worst-case time complexity
Explanation: Quick Sort generally uses less memory than Merge Sort.

Question: What is a characteristic of Quick Sort when the pivot element is always the greatest or the smallest element?

Choice B: It results in the worst performance
Choice C: It does not change the performance
Choice D: It makes Quick Sort a stable sort
Explanation: If the pivot is always largest or smallest, Quick Sort hits worst performance.

Question: Which of the following is true about Quick Sort?
Choice A: It is a stable sorting algorithm
Choice B: It is a comparison-based sorting algorithm
Choice C: It is not a comparison-based sorting algorithm

Question: A unit on bus that initiates bus requests is called

Question: A scheme in which portions of I/O address space are given to I/O devices, is called

Question: The DMA differs from the interrupt mode by
Choice A: The involvement of the processor for the operation (1)
Choice B: The method accessing the I/O devices (2)
Choice C: The amount of data transfer possible (3)

Question: The DMA transfers are performed by a control circuit called as
Explanation: A dedicated DMA controller handles these transfers.

Question: In DMA transfers, the required signals and addresses are given by the
Explanation: The DMA controller supplies signals and addresses.

Explanation: After DMA completes, the processor gets an interrupt signal.

Question: The controller is connected to the ____

Explanation: A single DMA controller cannot handle two disks simultaneously.

Question: The technique whereby the DMA controller steals the access cycles of the processor to operate is called
Explanation: Gaining memory access cycles from the CPU is called cycle stealing.

Question: The technique where the controller is given complete access to main memory is ________________________
Explanation: Giving full memory access is known as burst mode.

Question: The controller uses _____ to help with the transfers when handling network interfaces.
Explanation: The controller can use many aids (buffers, etc.) so all mentioned.

Question: To overcome the conflict over the possession of the BUS we use ______
Explanation: A bus arbitrator resolves conflicts for bus possession.

Question: If a unit completes its task before the allotted time period, then _______
Choice A: It'll perform some other task in the remaining time
Choice B: Its time gets reallocated to a different task
Choice C: It'll remain idle for the remaining time

Question: To increase the speed of memory access in pipelining, we make use of _______
Explanation: Cache is used to speed memory access in pipelines.

Question: For the addition of large integers, most of the systems make use of ______
Explanation: Carry look-ahead adders are often used for large integer addition.

Question: The register used to store the flags is called as _________
Explanation: The flags typically reside in a status register.

Question: In the implementation of a Multiplier circuit in the system we make use of _______
Explanation: A multiplier circuit typically uses shift registers.

Question: An 24 bit address generates an address space of ______ locations.
Explanation: A 24-bit address allows 2^24 = 16777216 locations.

Question: If a system is 64 bit machine, then the length of each word will be _______
Explanation: 64 bits = 8 bytes per word.

Question: When using the Big Endian assignment to store a number, the sign bit of the number is stored in _____
Choice A: The higher order byte of the word
Choice B: The lower order byte of the word
Explanation: In big-endian, the sign bit is in the high-order byte.

Question: To get the physical address from the logical address generated by CPU we use ____________
Explanation: An MMU translates logical to physical addresses.

Question: _____ method is used to map logical addresses of variable length onto physical memory.
Explanation: Segmentation maps variable-length regions.

Question: When generating physical addresses from a logical address the offset is stored in __________
Explanation: The low address bits (offset) are tracked in the page table.

Question: The technique used to store programs larger than the memory is ____________
Explanation: Overlays allow programs bigger than memory to run.

Question: The unit which acts as an intermediate agent between memory and backing store to reduce process time is ___________
Explanation: A cache helps between memory and secondary store.

Question: Does the Load instruction do the following operation/s?
Choice A: Loads the contents of a disc onto a memory location
Choice B: Loads the contents of a location onto the accumulators
Choice C: Load the contents of the PCB onto the register
Explanation: A Load instruction moves data from memory to a register.

Question: Which of the following techniques used to effectively utilize main memory?
Explanation: Dynamic linking and loading help main memory usage.

Question: __________ converts the programs written in assembly language into machine instructions.
Explanation: An assembler translates assembly language to machine code.

Question: The return address of the Sub-routine is pointed to by _______
Explanation: The return address is held by the PC upon subroutine call.

Question: The order in which the return addresses are generated and used is _________
Explanation: Return addresses follow LIFO order.

Question: In case of nested subroutines the return addresses are stored in __________
Explanation: Nested calls store return addresses on the processor stack.

Question: When parameters are being passed on to the subroutines they are stored in ________
Explanation: Parameters can be passed in registers, memory, or stack.

Question: The most efficient way of handling parameter passing is by using ______
The most Flexible way of logging the return addresses of the subroutines is by using _______
Explanation: Stacks allow flexible storage of return addresses for multiple nested calls

Question: ______ pointer is used to point to parameters passed or local parameters of the subroutine.
Explanation: A frame pointer helps access local variables and parameters within a subroutine

Question: The reserved memory or private space of the subroutine gets deallocated when _______
Choice A: The stop instruction is executed by the routine
Choice B: The pointer reaches the end of the space
Choice C: When the routine's return statement is executed
Explanation: Memory used by a subroutine is freed once its return executes

Question: _____ the most suitable data structure used to store the return addresses in the case of nested subroutines.
Explanation: A stack best supports nesting by storing multiple return addresses

Question: The data structure suitable for scheduling processes is _______
Explanation: A queue ensures orderly scheduling and fair allocation of CPU time

Question: The sub-routine service procedure is similar to that of the interrupt service routine in ________
Choice D: Method of context switch & Process execution
Explanation: Subroutine service is similar to interrupts in context switching and execution

Question: The usual BUS structure used to connect the I/O devices is ___________
Explanation: A single bus structure often connects the CPU and I/O devices

Question: The method of accessing the I/O devices by repeatedly checking the status flags is ___________
Explanation: Program-controlled I/O repeatedly checks device status flags before proceeding

Question: The process wherein the processor constantly checks the status flags is called as ___________
Explanation: Polling describes continuously reading status flags to detect events

Question: The interrupt-request line is a part of the ___________
Explanation: The interrupt-request line belongs to the control signals section

Question: The return address from the interrupt-service routine is stored on the ___________
Explanation: The processor stack stores the address to resume after interrupt handling

Question: The signal sent to the device from the processor to the device after receiving an interrupt is ___________
Explanation: After an interrupt, the CPU sends an interrupt-acknowledge signal to the device

Question: The time between the receiver of an interrupt and its service is ______
Explanation: Interrupt latency is the delay from interrupt request to its actual service

Question: Interrupts form an important part of _____ systems.
Explanation: Real-time processing systems rely heavily on interrupt mechanisms

Question: The resistor which is attached to the service line is called _____
Explanation: A pull-up resistor is added to ensure a default high logic on the service line

Question: An interrupt that can be temporarily ignored is ___________
Explanation: A maskable interrupt can be switched off or deferred temporarily

Question: CPU as two modes privileged and non-privileged. In order to change the mode from privileged to non-privileged.
Choice C: Either hardware or software interrupt is needed
Choice D: A non-privileged instruction (which does not generate an interrupt)is needed
Explanation: To go from privileged to non-privileged mode, a software interrupt is needed

Question: How can the processor ignore other interrupts when it is servicing one ___________
Choice A: By turning off the interrupt request line
Choice B: By disabling the devices from sending the interrupts
Explanation: The processor can disable or ignore other interrupts while handling one

Question: In vectored interrupts, how does the device identify itself to the processor?
Choice B: By sending the machine code for the interrupt service routine
Choice C: By sending the starting address of the service routine
Explanation: In vectored interrupts, the device sends the start address of its service routine

Question: The processor indicates to the devices that it is ready to receive interrupts ________
Choice A: By enabling the interrupt request line
Choice C: By activating the interrupt acknowledge line
Explanation: The CPU activates the interrupt acknowledge line to accept new interrupts

Question: _________ method is used to establish priority by serially connecting all devices that request an interrupt.
Explanation: A daisy chain links devices in series to establish interrupt priority

Question: In daisy chaining device 0 will pass the signal only if it has _______
Choice C: Both No interrupt and Interrupt request
Explanation: Device 0 passes the interrupt signal only if it has no interrupt request

Question: If during the execution of an instruction an exception is raised then __________
Choice A: The instruction is executed and the exception is handled
Choice B: The instruction is halted and the exception is handled
Choice C: The processor completes the execution and saves the data and then handle the exception
Explanation: The instruction stops, and the exception is handled immediately

Question: _____ is/are types of exceptions.
Explanation: Traps, interrupts, and system calls are all considered exceptions

Question: A privilege exception is raised __________
Choice A: When a process tries to change the mode of the system
Choice B: When a process tries to change the priority level of the other processes
Choice C: When a process tries to access the memory allocated to other users
Explanation: A privilege exception is raised for disallowed mode or memory access attempts

Question: To resolve the clash over the access of the system BUS we use ______
Explanation: A bus arbitrator decides which component gets bus access first

Question: ______ BUS arbitration approach uses the involvement of the processor.
Explanation: Centralised arbitration involves the processor in the bus arbitration process

Question: The primary function of the BUS is __________
Choice A: To connect the various devices to the cpu
Choice B: To provide a path for communication between the processor and other devices
Choice C: To facilitate data transfer between various devices
Explanation: The bus links CPU and devices, enabling all data transfers

Question: The classification of BUSes into synchronous and asynchronous is based on __________
Explanation: Synchronous vs asynchronous buses differ by data-transfer timing

Question: The device which interacts with the initiator is __________
Explanation: The slave device responds to the initiating master device

Question: In synchronous BUS, the devices get the timing signals from __________
Choice C: Timing signals are not used at all
Explanation: In a synchronous bus, all devices share one common clock line

Question: The time for which the data is to be on the BUS is affected by __________
Choice D: Propagation delay of the circuit & Setup time of the device
Explanation: Propagation and setup times determine how long data must stay on the bus

Question: The duration between the read and the mfc signal is ______
Explanation: Access time is the interval between issuing a read and receiving MFC

Question: The minimum time delay between two successive memory read operations is ______
Explanation: Cycle time is the minimum gap required between consecutive reads

Question: __________ is the bottleneck, when it comes computer performance.
Explanation: Memory access time is the principal bottleneck in computer performance

Question: The number of external connections required in 16 X 8 memory organisation is _____
Explanation: A 16 X 8 memory needs 4 address, 8 data, plus control lines, total 14

Question: In a 4K-bit chip organisation has a total of 19 external connections, then it has _______ address if 8 data lines are there.
Explanation: A 4K-bit chip with 8 data lines and 19 pins means 9 address lines

Question: The drawback of building a large memory with DRAM is ______________
Explanation: DRAM-based large memory is slower and needs refresh

Question: The memory which is used to store the copy of data or instructions stored in larger memories, inside the CPU is called _______
Explanation: Level 1 cache in the CPU stores recently accessed instructions/data copies

Question: The next level of memory hierarchy after the L2 cache is _______
Explanation: After L2 cache, the next larger, slower memory is main memory

Question: The effectiveness of the cache memory is based on the property of ________
Explanation: Caches work well because of locality of reference in code and data

Question: The temporal aspect of the locality of reference means ________
Choice A: That the recently executed instruction won't be executed soon
Choice B: That the recently executed instruction is temporarily not referenced
Choice C: That the recently executed instruction will be executed soon again
Explanation: Temporal locality means recently accessed items are likely referenced again soon

Question: The spatial aspect of the locality of reference means ________
Choice A: That the recently executed instruction is executed again next
Choice B: That the recently executed won't be executed again
Choice C: That the instruction executed will be executed at a later time
Choice D: That the instruction in close proximity of the instruction executed will be executed in future
Explanation: Spatial locality means nearby addresses tend to be accessed close together

Question: The correspondence between the main memory blocks and those in the cache is given by _________
Explanation: A mapping function links main memory blocks to cache lines

Question: The algorithm to remove and place new contents into the cache is called _______
Explanation: A replacement algorithm chooses which cache line to evict for new data

Question: The write-through procedure is used ________
Choice A: To write onto the memory directly
Choice B: To write and read from memory simultaneously
Choice C: To write directly on the memory and the cache simultaneously
Explanation: Write-through updates both cache and memory on every write

Question: The bit used to signify that the cache location is updated is ________
Explanation: The dirty bit indicates a cache line has changed and needs write-back

Question: The copy-back protocol is used ________
Choice A: To copy the contents of the memory onto the cache
Choice B: To update the contents of the memory from the cache
Choice C: To remove the contents of the cache and push it on to the memory
Explanation: Copy-back updates memory only when a dirty cache line is evicted

Question: The approach where the memory contents are transferred directly to the processor from the memory is called ______
Explanation: Early-start sends data from memory directly to the processor

Question: During a write operation if the required block is not present in the cache then ______ occurs.
Explanation: If a cache block is absent on a write, it is a write miss

Question: In memory interleaving, the lower order bits of the address is used to _____________
Choice B: Get the address of the module
Choice C: Get the address of the data within the module
Explanation: In memory interleaving, the lower bits select which memory module is used

Question: The number successful accesses to memory stated as a fraction is called as _____
Explanation: Hit rate is the fraction of successful cache accesses

Question: The number failed attempts to access memory, stated in the form of a fraction is called as _________
Explanation: Miss rate is the fraction of cache accesses that fail to find the data

Question: In associative mapping during LRU, the counter of the new block is set to '0' and all the others are incremented by one, when _____ occurs.
Explanation: On a miss, the new block's counter is reset, others are incremented

Question: In LRU, the referenced blocks counter is set to'0' and that of the previous blocks are incremented by one and others remain same, in the case of ______
Explanation: On a hit, the accessed block's counter is reset, some others increment

Question: The program is divided into operable parts called as _________
Explanation: The program is divided into fixed-size pages for memory management

Question: The techniques which move the program blocks to or from the physical memory is called as ______
Explanation: Overlays move selected program parts in or out of physical memory

Question: The binary address issued to data or instructions are called as ______
Explanation: The binary address given to data or instructions is called a logical address

Question: ______ translates the logical address into a physical address.
Explanation: The MMU converts a logical address into the corresponding physical address

Question: The main aim of virtual memory organisation is ________
Choice C: To improve the execution of the program
Explanation: Virtual memory aims to improve overall program execution and efficiency

Question: The numbers written to the power of 10 in the representation of decimal numbers are called as _____
Explanation: Powers of ten in decimal notation are called scale factors

Question: ________ constitute the representation of the floating number.
Explanation: A floating-point number consists of sign, mantissa, and exponent

Question: The sign followed by the string of digits is called as ______
Explanation: The signed digit string is referred to as the mantissa

Question: The 32 bit representation of the decimal number is called as ___________
Explanation: A 32-bit floating-point representation is single-precision

Question: In 32 bit representation the scale factor as a range of ________
Explanation: The 8-bit exponent field ranges from 0 to 255 in single-precision

Question: In double precision format, the size of the mantissa is ______
Explanation: Double precision uses a 52-bit mantissa
